string.text: Those who have long trampled the Zone, as far as I know, are interested in something other than dough, booze and a wish fulfiller. Maybe I'm wrong, but I think I heard in the bar, that there is a fashion for philosophical sayings among you. You want to tell me a funny parable?
Oh, thank you.
Thank you. (chuckles)

Well, there's a tendency among experienced walkers. We get hooked on one thing and then another. Listen. The story goes that once King Mahmud overtook his retinue. As he was riding at full gallop along the river, he suddenly saw a little boy by the water catching a seine. The child seemed very unhappy. The king sharply stopped the horse, and approaching the boy, he asked him: - My child, why do you look so sad? I've never met a sadder man than you. The boy replied: Your Majesty, there are seven of us brothers. Our father is dead and we live with our mother in dire need. To get by, I go to the river every day and cast a net. If I don't catch a single fish in a day, I stay hungry for the night. My son," said the king, "if you don't mind, I will help you. The boy agreed, and King Mahmud cast the net himself, which at the touch of the king's hand came back with a rich catch.

Huh, when you've been balancing life and death for years, any fool will sooner or later become a philosopher. So listen. A man's out in the field sowing wheat. The day is coming to an end, and he can't finish his work... He prayed: Oh, Lord, if I had a helper, we'd be done sowing in no time... Look, a bear crawled out of the bushes and said to him: "Come on, man, I will help you, it will be more fun together. The man was delighted and agreed. They sowed the field on time and hugged each other goodbye... It's harvest time... The man didn't have time to reap the harvest... Look, a familiar bear crawled out of the bushes and said: "Come on, man, I'll help you, it's easier for both of us". And the work started... They've harvested crops the man has never seen before. So he says to the bear: "Come on, Mishenka, let's go to my house. You helped me sow and reap... Let's go and sit at the table: let's drink, eat, talk... The bear agreed, the man's generosity pleased him. They are sitting at the table, rejoice, and the bear keeps saying: "Well, man, if it weren't for me, you wouldn't have sown the whole field... If it wasn't for me, you wouldn't have had such a harvest... And the man thinks: "Look how big and strong he is, he'll take everything from me and break my bones... He's praising himself for a reason..." The man grabs the pitchfork and stabs the bear. The bear roared in pain... ...and runs off into the woods. Time passed... ...and the sowing season came again... The man went out into the field to sow, but without a helper, only half of the field was sown. It's harvest time, but he's only halfway through the harvest... He walks home, despondent... He sees a bear crawling out of the bushes. The man says reproachfully: "Why didn't you come to help me sow and reap...? I gave you food and water, and you?" To which the bear, pointing to his chest, replies: "I have a pain here..." The man walks up to the bear, gropes and says: "It's all healed, Misha!" And the bear says: "The wound has healed... IT HURTS!!!"

Well - we're not so much over-the-top philosophers. Just lovers of reading things that really have value. So here's a story. An unknown poet once came to a king and said: - "O king, who has no equal in the heavens! I have composed a hymn in your honour, and my creation is brighter than all the verses that other poets have hitherto composed for you, as Sirius is brighter than all the lights in the night sky. With these words he handed the king a sheet on which was written only the name of this ruler. The king looked at the sheet and became angry: - Where are the verses? - he shouted. - Have you gone mad? You did not sing of our royal glory, you did not sing of our victories and our good deeds. You have not even mentioned that I have made this kingdom with my own hands! You dare to mock me? But the poet was not frightened by the king's anger and replied with dignity: - All the king's wisdom, mercy and might and all military glory are contained in this name, and anyone who reads it will at once imagine all the deeds accomplished by the king. For the name is the symbol of thy kingdom, and it is in itself above the thickest book of eulogies. So I was right before you when I called what was written by my hand an incomparable hymn glorifying you and your deeds!

Hmmm, now I recall one of the last. A long time ago in the Middle Kingdom (as China was then called), the best, mightiest fighters of the world gathered for a tournament. The contest was judged by a great Chinese sage. Finally, after thousands of battles, he chose three of the greatest warriors and asked each of them to tell him how they trained. The great, fierce-looking fighter was the first to rise and say: 'Every morning at sunrise I break down trees, stones, planks - anything that comes my way. All around my dwelling for a day's journey is turned to ashes, a desert. - That's fine," said the wise man. - And how do you train? - he asked another fighter. A tall, thin man, more like a monk or an ascetic, came up. - Every morning at sunrise, he said, "I meditate. I take my body under the control of mind and will and make it as light and quick as a thought. - Perfect," said the sage. - How do you train? - He asked the third warrior. An ordinary looking man, unremarkable in appearance, stood up. If he hadn't won a thousand fights recently, no one would have guessed he was a warrior and a great one at that. - I don't train at all," said the third man. - I just try to be present in everything I do.

Now that someone here understands us. I say. I think I've had an epiphany. So listen. Once upon a time, there was Godelo. He had a wife who was always nagging him about his father interfering with their lives, and Godelo couldn't calm his wife down. Godelo's father, listening to his wife's cries day after day, called his son and said to him: - Son, I see that I am disturbing your family welfare with my presence, let me go to the mountains to live... - Godelo listened to his father and at first he refused, but there was nothing to do... The father started to get ready as he called his son to him and said: - I have just one problem: I will not be able to get to the mountains on my own, why don't you carry me in the basket on your shoulders and I will help myself. - "All right," said Godelo, agreeing. He put his father in a basket and carried him up the mountain. He brought his father, dropped him off, and was about to leave when his father followed him: - Wait, son, don't forget to take your basket, your son may need it. Godelo felt ashamed, realized his mistake, repented, put his father back in the basket and brought him home. ...and threw his wicked wife out of the house.

Well, there's a tendency among experienced walkers. We get hooked on one thing and then another. Listen. One pilgrim walked many thousands of steps to meet the Teacher and finally stood before him, asking to share the highest wisdom. - Then take a sip from this stream and describe to me the taste of the water. - The teacher told him. - I have already heard and understood this Truth, said the seeker a little disappointed. - Tell me, what do you understand? - Teacher asked. - Water cannot be described by words; you have to drink it and not talk about it, the same goes for Truth... - Now imagine - I'm sitting near a stream, and a crowd of people like you are standing in line for me to describe the taste of water to them, even though many of them have already heard this description from other Gurus.

When you've been balancing life and death for years, any fool will sooner or later become a philosopher. So listen. A girl was walking along the road, beautiful as a fairy. Suddenly she noticed a man following her. She turned around and asked: - Tell me, why are you following me? The man replied: - O lord of my heart, your charms are so irresistible that they command me to follow you. They say that I play the lute, that I am privy to the mysteries of poetry and that I can awaken the anguish of love in the hearts of women. And to you I want to declare my love, because you have captivated my heart! The beautiful woman looked at him silently for a while, then said: - How could you fall in love with me? My little sister is much prettier and more attractive than me. She's coming after me, look at her. The man stopped, then turned around, but saw only an ugly old woman in a patched cloak. Then he quickened his steps to catch up with the girl. Lowering his eyes, he asked in a voice expressing resignation: - Tell me, how could a lie come out of your mouth? She smiled and replied: - You too, my friend, did not tell me the truth when you pledged your love. You know perfectly all the rules of love and pretend that your heart burns with love for me. How could you turn around to look at another woman?

Well - we're not so much over-the-top philosophers. Just lovers of reading things that really have value. So here's the story. A merchant sent his son to learn the Secret of Happiness from the wisest of men. The young man walked for forty days through the desert and finally came to a beautiful castle that stood on top of a mountain. The wise man he was looking for lived there. However, instead of the expected meeting with the wise man, our hero found himself in a room where everything was buzzing: traders were coming and going, people were talking in the corner, a small orchestra was playing sweet melodies and there was a table full of the most exquisite dishes of the area. The sage was talking to various people and the young man had to wait about two hours for his turn. The wise man listened attentively to his explanation of the purpose of his visit, but answered that he did not have time to tell him the Secret of Happiness. He suggested he take a walk around the palace and come back in two hours. - However, I have one favour to ask," the wise man added as he handed the young man a small spoon in which he dropped two drops of oil. - Keep this spoon in your hand the whole time you are walking so that the oil does not spill out. The young man began to go up and down the palace stairs, keeping his eyes on the spoon. After two hours he returned to the sage. - Well," he asked, "have you seen the Persian carpets that are in my dining room? Have you seen the park which the head gardener has been creating for ten years? Have you noticed the beautiful parchments in my library? The young man had to confess in embarrassment that he had seen nothing. His only concern was not to spill the drops of oil the wise man had entrusted to him. - Well, go back and see the wonders of my universe," the wise man told him. - You cannot trust a man if you are not familiar with the house in which he lives. Relieved, the young man took the spoon and again went for a walk around the palace; this time, paying attention to all the works of art hung on the walls and ceilings of the palace. He saw the gardens surrounded by mountains, the delicate flowers, the delicacy with which each of the works of art had been placed exactly where it was needed. Returning to the sage, he described in detail all that he had seen. - Where are the two drops of oil I entrusted to you? - The wise man asked. Nathan looked at the spoon and saw that all the oil had been poured out. - That is the only advice I can give you: the secret of happiness is to look at all the wonders of the world and never forget the two drops of oil in your spoon.

Hmmm, now I recall one of the last. Once upon a time in an Indian kingdom-state, there was an old monarch who spent his whole life deciding one purely Oriental question: what is the essence of power? He finally decided to find the strongest man in his kingdom in order to learn from him what the essence of strength was. As a reward for that hero the Indian tsar nominated a horse from his stables, and at the request of the winner of the contest: if he wants white - he gets a white horse, if he wants black - he gets a black one. To solve this difficult task associated with the eternal problem of choice, he gathered the wisest men of his kingdom and sent them to inspect the towns and villages. The monarch's task was indeed an unusually difficult one - the wise men had walked in many a pair of sandals, but they had not found the strongest man. They arranged competitions, gave many tasks to the aspirants to win, but the effect was zero: none of the subjects of the Indian king could unreservedly claim the right to be called the strongest man of the Indian kingdom. The wise men had already despaired of finding a man to whom they could hand over one of the best horses in the royal stable... These "experts" were scratching their heads! They were not able to bear their own heads. Suddenly, while they were passing through a small village in India, they noticed a giant man. He was lying on a huge trestle bed in the middle of a large garden surrounding his house. "What immense power is hidden in this man!" - the wise men exclaimed and decided to put him to three tests. "Can you break a horseshoe with one hand?" - the wise men asked the giant man. The man answered them nothing, but simply broke the horseshoe with his hand. "Can you uproot the tree?" - Again the wise men asked him. He answered them nothing, but simply put his two hands around the ten metre high tree and pulled it out of the ground in one fell swoop. "Truly you are strong, man! But can you block the river?" - the wise men asked a third time. The giant man answered them nothing, but approached the river, lifted a huge stone lying on the bank into the air and threw it into the stream, and the river stood up. "Praise the gods! - exclaimed the wise men. - Truly you are the strongest man on earth! Choose any of the king's horses: take the black one if you want, take the white one if you want!" And just as the giant man put his hand above his head to scratch the back of his head before announcing his decision, a small, puny woman in a dark outfit suddenly appeared on his doorstep. "Husband, I warn you: if you choose a white man, you'll be in trouble! I can't vouch for myself!"

Well, now someone's starting to understand. Oh, man. I've had an epiphany in my life. So listen. There was a time when Genghis Khan was approached by the wife of a prince, asking her to free her relatives. Genghis Khan said: - Here, before you stand your husband, your son, and your brother. I will release only one, who will you choose? Without thinking, she answered: - My brother. - Explain to me why? The woman said: - I can find a husband, I can give birth to a son, but I cannot create a brother. After hearing this, Genghis Khan released all three.

Well, how can I tell you, there is such a tendency among experienced walkers. We get hooked on one thing and then another. Listen. ...The gates of Zhongdu swung open, and steppe tribesmen streamed into the richest city in the Celestial Empire, shrieking and waving their weapons furiously. Li Cui, known in Zhundu as Nosy Li, a stray of no lineage, who had come to the city from unknown climes just prior to the invasion, was a frail and disheveled Li Cui, limping through the lanes of the western suburbs, hoping for fortune. If the great Guanyin helps him escape unharmed, he will become a shaved-headed saffron-robed monk, living on alms and indifferent to mundane concerns - and may other fools give perilous advice to the feeble-minded Son of Heaven, the dumbass emperor, and may the poor Celestial be raped and pillaged by any and all, be it greedy dignitaries, dirty Mongols, or... Before he realized that Guanyin was now looking in a different direction, Nosy Li halted abruptly, hissing in pain at his bruised knee, and hauling the short, three-elbowed staff to his chest. At the end of the lane, a tall, leather-clad Mongol grinned cheerfully, brandishing a long spear with a crossbar beneath its spearhead tube. The disgraced warlord Li Kui, called Nosy Li in Zhundu and Blue Tiger Hou in the capital, sighed deeply and walked slowly toward the smirking steppeman, an effort of will forcing himself to stop limping. The mongol waited until the frail ragamuffin approached, and lazily jabbed his spear in front of him. A moment later the weapon was almost torn from his grasp, and when the astonished warrior jerked backward, holding the lance upward, a hollowed out staff flew into his face, hiding like a silkworm in a cocoon from prying eyes the Blue Tiger Hou's straight sword-jian. The city was already on fire. Bitter smoke wafted through the streets of Zhongdu, ahead of the looting warriors of the indomitable Temujin Genghis Khan; The smoke rushed ahead of the invaders, making its way to the western outskirts, the acrid smoke made the throat farther and the leg of Li Kui unbearably sore, and the Mongol struck skillfully and ferociously, now with the tip, now with the back of the shaft, And so much had to move until Guanyin deigned to turn her benevolent gaze to Zhundu and to the abandoned alley, where Nosy Li had twice managed to reach the Mongol's wrists with his blade. Now all that was left was to wait. To wait and not to fall under the spear, whose movements became more and more unsteady and trembling. And when they waited - to put the last forces in a last jump. ...He never let go of his spear, this unlucky warrior in light leather armor. Coughing and cowering, he sat against the wall of someone's house, clutching his pierced side with his right hand while his left continued to rest on a lance. And above them, over the wounded Mongol and the powerless spear, breathing heavily and trying not to shift his weight on his injured leg, stood Li Kui, the former commander of Li's left wing, the former Blue Tiger Hou, the former Nosy Li, the future abbot of the monastery near Mount Utayshan, a tired little man. Standing there, he watched the Mongol's face grow increasingly pale and his splitting wrists bleed less and less. The Mongol raised his head with difficulty - and their gazes met. Li Kui sighed, tore his cloak into strips, crouched beside the Mongol and began to bandage the invincible Genghis warrior's hands tightly. Lee didn't know why he was doing this...

Heh, when you've been balancing life and death for years any fool sooner or later becomes a philosopher. So listen. The king's daughter was as beautiful as the moon and enchanted all who were lucky enough to get a glimpse of her. One day a dervish was about to eat some bread and was about to eat it when he suddenly saw her and froze in amazement. His fingers were unclenched and the bread fell to the ground. As he passed by, the Princess smiled at the dervish. His body shook with delight, the bread was left lying in the dust and he almost lost his senses. The dervish remained in that state for seven years. The street became his home and stray dogs his neighbours. The Princess was fed up with the mad dervish and her bodyguards decided to kill him. She summoned him to her house and told him - No alliance between us is possible. You must leave the city immediately, because my servants want to kill you. The unhappy lover answered her thus: - Since I have seen you, life has no value to me. They will shed innocent blood. But before I die, I beseech thee, grant me my one wish, for thou art the cause of my ruin. Tell me, why then did you smile at me? - Fool!" said the Princess. - When I saw what a laugh you made of yourself, I smiled out of pity, that is all. And, having said that, the princess fled.

Well, we're not so great philosophers. Just lovers of reading things that really have value. So here's the story. There was a conversation between two wise men about love. One said: - It is the nature of love to always bring torment and distress, and the one in love is always tormented and suffering. The other objected: - Shut up, you have apparently never experienced the sweetness of reconciliation after a quarrel and have never known the taste of connection after separation. No one in the world is purer and gentler than the pure of heart in love, and no one is dirtier than those who are far from the thought of love. In the beauty of a man's heart is the glow of love's glow: If the heart is ugly, it does not honour beauty! Let the ignorant remember the sayings of the wise: Where the breed honours the breed, the souls are confirmed.

Hm, I recall a recent one. There once was a man who was obsessed by a mad love and was tormented by love. The beauty of the one he loved was incomparable even to the beauty of heavenly maidens. She was said to outshine the sun and the moon by her beauty. And in addition this her incomparable beauty was dangerous for people not only because it threatened everyone with the torment of love, but also because this beauty was clever and ruthless. And so one day a man in love with her, thinking he was alone, said to himself: - My God! Her face is more beautiful than a rose and her trunk more slender than a cypress! Her whole appearance is brighter than a peacock, and her gait is more graceful than that of a pheasant! It turned out that his beloved was nearby at the time and had heard his words. Openly she stood before him and said: - You probably wanted to flatter me with your comparisons, but they have only angered me, and I consider them for myself as shameful. You have compared my face to a rose, but where have you seen such beautiful eyes and eyebrows as mine? You have compared my loin to a cypress, but does the cypress have my mobility and ardour? You have compared my whole appearance to that of a peacock, but has anyone ever burned with love when contemplating peacocks? You have compared my walk to that of a pheasant, but who among men will ever soothe his soul in the recollection of a walking pheasant? - Forgive me! - cried the lover. - I foolishly imagined that you could be described in words! The words made the moon-faced woman all the more furious and she said in fury: - For this foolishness of yours, I will have you! Then the lover fell at her feet with the words: - O incomparable unearthly Beauty! All my unspeakable speeches were caused by my true and pure love for thee. There is no malice, no reproach or even any complaint in them, and if they seemed inappropriate to thee, kindly do not charge me harshly for this fault, consider them a sign of my ignorance and ignorance, and I myself shall then perish from shame and disgrace! And so long did he seek and utter the words of repentance that the beauty was pacified and gave up her intention of taking revenge on this man who was in love with her.

Well, at least someone has begun to understand us. Well, well, well. So much for an epiphany in life. So listen. There was a thief in the old days. One day he robbed the treasury of the sultan. The padishah sent all his detectives after him. The thief was caught and his loot taken away. Then the sultan asked his chief vizier: - What to do with this thief? - All the people of the city should be gathered and the thief should be slaughtered in front of all the people," replied the vizier. The Emperor had a daughter. The padishah asked her: - Is the Vizier right? - The Vizier reasoned in essence," replied the girl. Then the padishah asked the middle vizier: - What to do with this thief? - We must stack more firewood, put the thief on it and set it on fire. Again the padishah asked his daughter: - How do you find what the vizier said? And the daughter of the Vizier answered again: - Your vizier has reasoned in essence. Finally the Padishah asked his younger vizier: - What to do with the thief? - We should clothe the thief from head to toe, give him everything so that his belly is always full, and let him go. The Padishah again asked his daughter: - How do you find what the Vizier said? - 'Your vizier has reasoned in essence,' the girl replied. Then the padishah said: - 'You said of each of the three viziers that he reasoned in essence. What do you mean by that, explain it to us. And the girl answered: - The chief vizier, who said that the thief should be slaughtered, must be of butchers by birth. Your middle vizier must be of brick-firing stock. And the younger vizier is by all accounts a nobleman. The Padishah checked and it turned out that the girl was right. The thief was dealt with as the junior vizier advised: he was fed to his heart's content, given money for expenses and spared from death. And the junior vizier was made chief vizier.

Well, how can I tell you, there is such a tendency among experienced walkers. We get hooked on one thing and then another. Listen. Once a gang of robbers went out to plunder. Once they'd got a lot of stuff, they started to divide it up amongst themselves. All the shares were equal, and only a dress made of the finest thread - it was considered to be the worst share - was given to the weakest in the gang. And the weakest one, having received his share, became enraged. He began to shout that he had been outmanoeuvred. When he came to the city to sell his garment, all the rich men started to offer him a lot of money. What he got on his own was twice what all his companions got together. Then he rejoiced and jumped for joy. It is like the laymen who, not knowing whether giving alms will result in a reward or not, give out a small amount of alms (part of their income). But when they are reborn in heaven and experience immense bliss, they begin to regret - they regret that they did not give out extensive alms (their entire fortune). They are like one who, having received large sums of money for a dress, rejoices. It is the same with giving alms. That's why along with rejoicing they have regrets for the incompleteness of the deed.

Huh, when you're balancing between life and death for years any fool sooner or later becomes a philosopher. So listen. Once upon a time there was a family: husband, wife and daughter. The family was poor, poor, and could barely make ends meet. The husband and wife began to think how they could get rich. - We're living in poverty now. Let's look for a rich man, settle down with him, see what he is doing, and we will imitate him in everything. So they did. They broke down their hut and built a new one next to the rich setkhei's house. The setkhei made his workers work the field and vegetable garden and then sent them out to sell the crops. The poor tried to imitate the setkhei in what they could, working in the field and then selling part of the harvest in the bazaar. Gradually they were doing better and better and their income was increasing. The husband and wife decided to thank the setkhei from whom they had learned to farm in secret. The husband took a handful of gold and went to the rich man. - Why have you brought me gold? - The sethei wondered. - I was a poor man. So my wife and I decided to destroy our hut and settle near your house and imitate you in all things. Our business quickly improved, the family became rich, and out of gratitude we asked you to accept our gift. - Since you yourself believe that you have acquired all your wealth thanks to me, then it is my wealth. You should give me all your fortune and I will decide for you what share to give. - But I did not remain ungrateful and brought you the gold. If I had known that you would demand my entire fortune, I would have brought you nothing. Dutyo argued sethey and the former poor man. Finally, they went to the judge. The judge could not settle their dispute, and took them both to the king. The former poor man bowed and said: - 'Your Majesty, I settled near the house of the setkhei and watched how he farms, how he sends his workers to work the field and to trade in the bazaar. I imitated the setkhei in whatever way I could, and achieved prosperity and good fortune in my affairs. Out of gratitude, I brought gold to the setkhei, who helped me without my knowing it, but the setkhei demands my entire fortune. Please, Your Majesty, sort out this matter justly. The King turned to the Sethei: - "Is this man's case correct? - All is right, Your Majesty. The king realized that the Sethei was greedy, and said: - Sethei, do you have children? - A son, Your Majesty. - And you? - The king turned to the former poor man. - A daughter, your majesty. - So that there will be no quarrel between you, I command the two families to intermarry. Then you will have nothing to share. Sethei and the former poor man bowed low to the king and left to follow the king's wise decision.

Well - we're not so much over-the-top philosophers. Just lovers of reading things that really have value. So here's the story. Once upon a time, there lived a hermit man in the desert. Once upon a time, he was a good carpenter in his homeland. But by chance, life took him to the desert. A rich man came to know about the master and sought him out: - "They say you are a good craftsman. So I want to order from you an oak table and chairs for my hall. I will come for my order in a month and I will pay you well. And he left. After the appointed time, the rich man came to the craftsman again and asked: - Where are my table and chairs? - Yes, I am a good craftsman. But this is not enough. In order for me to fulfill your order, I also need wood and tools, which I do not have... Desire alone is not enough: you also need capabilities...

Hm, I now recall one of the last. A letter arrived in Shamil's army informing some warrior that his wife had died. The letter was received by Shamil himself. He decided to check on that soldier and sent for him. When he arrived, Shamil said: - A letter has come for you with the news that your father has died. - If so, the roof of our house has fallen off, and I need to go home," replied the warrior. - No, not my father died, but your brother did. - Then the wall of the house collapsed and I have to go to the funeral. - It turned out that it was not your brother who had died, but your mother. - So the house started to fall down. I have to go home. - Not your mother, but your sister passed away. - A flower has fallen from my heart, I must go home. - I was checking up on you. In fact, your wife is dead. - If so, the whole house has fallen apart and there's nothing left of it. There's no reason for me to go home now.

I can't believe someone's starting to understand us. Well... I've had an epiphany in my life. So listen. There were two men driving towards each other. One was in a hurry to help his benefactor, the other was in a hurry to celebrate. They met on a narrow bridge and did not want to give way to each other. They argued and argued and went to the judge. The judge could not understand their case, so he took them both to the king. The king asked: - Explain to me why you didn't want to give way to each other. One of the disputants answered: - Your Majesty, I was in a hurry for the feast, I met this man on the bridge, but he would not let me pass. The second disputant said: - At one time a man did me a great favour. Now he was in trouble. I rushed to his aid. That is why I did not give way. The king ruled as follows: - The one who rushed to the feast must compensate the one who rushed to the aid of his benefactor.
What interesting things can you tell us about life?
Quite entertaining.

The regiment I served in had a rather large outbuildings. Decent-sized greenhouse, pigsty, and even had a horse called Buket. A soldier of Romani nationality looked after the pigs in the pigsty. One pig farrowed in winter. Everybody was rejoicing, the pigs were counted and weighed, and at night one of them died... In the morning, the deputy comes to see the farrower, and the gypsy (I don't remember his name) shows him the newly-born pig. So what to do? They wrote one off. And the gypsy, being a fool, didn't throw the piggy away, but threw it in a snowdrift. A day or two later, he takes one of the pigs alive (because of the age, I do not remember, whether he just ate it with his friends, or sold it to the locals), and the deputy clerk presents him the dead one, hiding it in a snowdrift. Another one was written off. And that one went back to the snowdrift. Alas, in a second attempt to trick the bosses in the same way, his swindle failed. The regiment commander was very angry when it was reported to him. He came to the pigsty personally. For some reason he particularly disliked the radio that stood in the room where the gypsy slept. It was a big, ancient radio in a wooden case. And he made the soldier drag the receiver from the pigsty to the parade ground, where the whole regiment was standing. And then to march along the square together with the receiver. And when the deputy officer asked, "How long?" He answered: "Till Nikolay Slitchenko sings...".

In the early 2000s I was actively involved in organising and preparing various charity events, where the main trump card was an opportunity to meet very serious people on an equal footing. And to help children, of course. While organising one of these events, which took place in a departmental hotel, I helped a woman from the "I can do anything, but I don't want anything for myself" class. In return for the enormous amount of work involved in preparing and collecting the money, I was promised some extremely valuable contacts among sponsors. Actually, at any charity event, especially a large-scale one, there are 4 main categories of people - the real sponsors, the organisers of the event with their various artists etc., and the "support staff". The organizers of the event with their various artists, "service personnel", children or other recipients of charity, and, actually, the category we would like to single out, because we will talk about it further - their majesties, the freeloaders. Of course not all of them are full-fledged freeloaders - some of them contribute a little to the fund to help children, but don't get me wrong, if they are preparing a banquet for sponsors for 100 quid per person, then they actually count not for 200 rubles for the lottery ticket they bought. At the very beginning of the event I looked around the hall and noticed each of the 4 groups of invitees. There weren't that many freeloaders this time - still the control was on the level, but still they were present, because the table was full of food and drinks, and the programme included celebrity performances and other goodies. The evening was divided into 2 parts - during the first part there was a story about for whom the money was raised, children's performance and in the closing there was a charity auction. It was the auction that revealed the total freeloaders. For they never buy anything and try not to show themselves in front of the auctioneer actively working with the hall, but often silently leave the hall during the auction (charity auctions differ by the fact that they often sell the work of children themselves, and without active work with the hall to promote children's creativity product, the proceeds of the auction will be miserable). It was at the auction, I was very surprised by the behavior of one of the freeloaders, who attracted my attention from the first glance into the hall. This was a guy of about 30 and a ponytail, completely rustic looking, very simply dressed (although freeloaders always try to blend in) and with the look of a child from a small Siberian town who was taken to the Kremlin Christmas tree for the first time in his life. The guy didn't even buy a raffle ticket, which completely killed me. There was a lot of organizing to do, and it all fell on my young shoulders (I was 22), but the event was responsible and, as they say in the famous movie "These are kids! In intermission the woman to whom I helped, has executed the promise and has actually acquainted me with some very serious people from Russia and not only. When I asked if there was anyone really cool, she hesitated and said she couldn't answer. Actually, even the contacts I received were quite enough for serious accomplishments, and I decided to score. During the second part there were performances by artists, which I was directly involved in organising. And whether the stars were aligned, or the atmosphere was favourable - in general, the festival was a success with a capital letter - the sponsors' eyes were burning, I was dripping with sweat and I ate nothing in the morning. A freeloader I spotted rejoiced like a child, clapped and ate in both cheeks. After the event, all the guests came around with a piggy bank and they poured a sum that no one really counted on, but the freeloaders shoved a hundred roubles each at best, while my village guest poured nothing at all. In general, the woman organiser was happy. When the guests started to leave, she said: "Okay, you've helped me a lot, I'll show you a 'hero of our time'. But you have to promise me that you won't tell anyone about him and won't ask him any questions - he's a very shy person and he's never really known for his help. This man has financed the construction of new buildings for 300 children in our orphanage and all the infrastructure, as well as the installation of a gas pipeline from the nearest village. I gave her my word. We walked out the hotel door together and she pointed me to the very country boy who was getting behind the wheel of an ordinary second-hand Volga. To say that there was a revolution in my mind is nothing to say. The fact that I personally saw this construction site, which was moving at a revolutionary speed. And even then I understood very well how much gas supply costs and who I had to be to approve it in such a short time. It was at that moment that the phrase "a really serious person" came to me. Since then, when I look at the "freeloaders" at such events, I always remember those childish, full of love and simple joy eyes, and look for such people among them. Sometimes I find them. And immediately I understand everything.

This story happened at the time when my uncle was in the Soviet army, around 1980. Somehow, two soldiers brought sand to their military unit on a ZIL truck. In principle, a dump truck is a very handy thing, you pull the lever, and the loose material falls out in a neat pile, succumbing to the laws of gravity. But as it was in deep autumn with rain and hoar-frost the sand in the truck body froze a little. And it didn't want to fall out as it was inclined. But the driver and his partner were an example of good mindedness and decided that in the highest point of body's rising the sand couldn't hold together in any case and it would fall down on the ground like a punishment from heaven. Usually, it happens this way, but our fellows didn't take into account that they had parked the truck on a slight slope. And the sand which is not falling out seriously raises the centre of gravity of their machine, as a result ZILok falls on a side (thus the sand at last come off from a body), in a cabin, naturally our soldiers fall at each other. The history, however, is rather habitual - dump trucks are overturned rather frequently. The most interesting thing happened immediately after the fall; a crowd of soldiers, who were observing the unloading process with interest, immediately ran up to the cab of the ZIL, smashed almost all the glass with their mighty pink boots and whatever materials were at hand, and pulled out two of our friends from the cab, grabbing for whatever they could; as a result, one of them had a torn uniform, the other one's face was scratched. As it turned out, the soldiers who were watching were frightened by the explosion and decided to heroically rescue our drivers...

I don't remember who told me this story, but it goes like this. This story took place in the days of the Soviet army. In one of the regions of our immense motherland there was a military unit, I do not remember what kind of unit it was. Whether infantry, or artillery, but it doesn't matter. Here and imagine, quiet, dark summer night, all part sleeps strong, heroic sleep. In one of barracks, as it is necessary to be awake, the sergeant on duty (an old-serviceman who has hardly more than a month left till demobilization) and the private (just called up "spirit") stand on the bedside table, struggling with sleep with all their might, And the sergeant takes a deep nap in the so-called "Lenin's room". I should note at once, as this will play a role in the future, the orderlies and attendants were equipped with only one weapon - the bayonet-knife, which was as strictly controlled as any other weapon. And then at one point, when the night was in full swing, the young soldier suddenly realized that either his stomach had not yet adapted to soldier food, or he had caught some kind of infection, or both. And that unless he takes urgent action, the entire contents of his bowels will drain into his boots. In an anguished whisper, so as not to wake up the company, he calls the officer on duty. In the same whisper, he swears and curses at the "spirits" that are keeping him from demobilizing, and asks the reason for the interruption of his sweet sleep. The young man quickly, clearly and concisely, as the military code teaches, states the reason for the alarm. The sergeant, grumbling and cursing all young men and their delicate mothers' stomachs again, lets the orderly go to the toilet, and himself stands at his post. The fruits of civilisation in the form of the sewer system did not arrive in this section, and for the needs of nature there was a wooden toilet, which stood alone, and in the most remote place, for three points, and without any partitions. And so the young man with enviable speed overcoming the distance from the barracks to the sanitary building, on the fly unbuttoning his ammunition, reclines over one of the holes and blissfully relaxed. And then, at the climax of the action, the bayonet knife, issued to defend the country, slips from his belt and falls into the hole with a mocking "boom". When the soldier realises what has happened, the force of his heel's urges increases threefold. The images in his head are of being judged for the loss of his weapon, but even worse, of what the sergeant will do to him... He is soaked with sweat that he crawls into the barracks and tells his sergeant everything. When the sergeant understands that he will be beaten up no less, and maybe even more, and that his demobee will be moved to the very end of the line, he already begins to feel sick to his stomach. But Russian soldier, as they say, is invincible and will find a way out of any situation. After some hesitation the sergeant comes up with what seems to him to be the only solution at the moment. He puts the young man in an OZK suit (regular army protective kit designed to protect against chemical weapons), a gas mask and sends him back. He sends him back, as if to say: go, dive, search and do not come back without a knife. The young man has started to carry out the order without thinking too much. But here is bad luck, at this very time, the officer on duty, a major in the Soviet army, has got a craving. He goes to the above-mentioned establishment and with a peaceful look settles over the hole. And now imagine the major's reaction, when out of the next box, suddenly something in a gas mask, covered in shit and holding a dagger in his hand comes out. As the assistant on duty later recounted, the major ran into the control room with wild eyes, one hand up his unbuttoned trousers and the other waving his service Makarov, he smelled like shit a mile away and shouted something about saboteurs or unclean forces. As a result the unit was put on alert. After some investigation, the two soldiers were given 15 days in the brig and the major was sent to get his nerves better.

It went like this. There were training jumps in one of the military units. The process of the jump itself, as such, with an ordinary airborne parachute (D-5) does not seem difficult enough. You fall out of the plane, count to yourself: "501, 502, 503" - and after that, having flown not less than 60 m, try to find the filled parachute dome above your head. Having found the canopy in the right place, you land carefully. Everything was going according to plan - you dropped out, opened the canopy, landed. But here's the trouble, one poor bastard was unlucky. No, the dome opened, but he didn't reach the ground. A gust of wind blew the dome to pine trees surrounding the landing site. And here's a vivid picture: a soldier hangs in the branches of a mighty ship pine at the height of 10 metres like a puppet. It's impossible to reach the trunk, it's possible to crawl up the slings, but the same problem of getting down on the ground arises. Usually, in such cases they open the reserve parachute (it is located on the chest) and, using its slings, descend to the ground. As the fighter is young, several advisers rushed to his aid. Having enjoyed the picture they all started shouting together: "Pull the spare! Then everything happened as in the movies. The frightened paratrooper took out his slingshot... ...cut the lines of the main parachute in one fell swoop and pulled the ring of the reserve parachute... Ð. S. I have to ascertain - the record on parachute jumps from extra low altitude was not established at that time...

There was a student nicknamed Yellow in my group at the military department. A unique swearer, apparently from the womb. Well and the usual trouble for students happened to him - during self-preparation his officer-teacher caught him keenly playing cards with one more idiot... that is a student. As a punishment they gave him a bucket of quick-drying paint, brushes and an order to paint all the tables and chairs in the lecture room. The work was done, handed over to the officer on duty, the brushes washed... The cleaning lady came the next morning to wash the floor and the first thing she did was to turn all the chairs upside down, placing them on the tables. Her second action was to go to the teacher's room, from where she returned with the deputy head of the department and showed him the three letters, familiar to everyone since childhood, repeated many times on the unpainted back side of the chairs. That same day a couple of cheerful painters appeared before the bright eyes of the head of the department. - What the hell are you students doing?" gently scolded them. Yellow suddenly sprang into line, clicked his heels and reported - Sorry comrade colonel, it came out! - How many times you blurted it out, - the colonel marvelled. - And that's how many times it came out, that's how many times I wrote, - phlegmatically finished Yellow...

I used to work in the institute of instrument-making in Moscow on Kutuzovsky; next to the entrance there is a monument to heroic pilot Valentina Grizodubova, those who have passed by it, surely noticed a granite woman with a flight helmet. In Soviet times they used to develop airborne radar systems there, but after the collapse of the USSR they mostly switched to commercial orders, you have to eat for something. And then the Ministry of Defence ordered me to create a kind of "black box", the purpose of which I will not talk about for obvious reasons. About the fact, that in the process of adjustment to sit in the technical compartment of A-50 for several hours is not to sit in the easy chair of "Boeing" and sip brandy, too, I will not tell, the story is not about it. Colonels-generals from the ministry came to inspect the prototype of our product. One of the points of the act of acceptance is the test of the tightness of the case. The casing has a tricky shape, but for simplicity of description let it be just a cube with one-meter edge. The method of leak test is purely Soviet, no complicated measuring instruments, the casing is sunk with a winch into a giant aquarium of thick Plexiglas, three meters deep. If air bubbles are seen floating in the water, the entire device is discarded, together with all the electronics inside, according to the test regulations. Have you ever seen abandoned factories in the movies? The room with the aquarium looked something like that, and the last time the aquarium was cleaned it was probably in the Soviet times. The water had become rusty and murky. The winch, which was pulling the tested product under the water, had been stolen a long time ago, probably scrapped. We called a worker to drown the body with his hands. Let me remind you that this is not a balloon - it is a big sealed aluminium cube. The worker did not manage to sink the cube on his own. We, simple engineers, refused to help the worker - our job is to come up with schemes, not to play with cubes. But the soldiers seized the worker's initiative, three men in uniforms with plenty of stars rolled up their sleeves, climbed the ramp around the aquarium and began pushing the stubborn cube down, shouting "and one! and two! and three! They almost succeeded in doing so. At the last moment the cube tumbled on its side, and all except the prudent worker could not hold on and ended up in the aquarium. Those standing nearby jumped away and shook the dirty water off their clothes, the "gurgle" was not a bad one. The aquarium began chaos, just try to imagine what was happening: soldiers trying to get out, someone constantly stepping on someone, sending him down (and the depth is three meters), then falls down himself, and stepped on him. A metal cube floating around a meter long circle complements the picture, and they tried to grab hold of it, as a lifebuoy, but it kept turning over and hitting the next resurfacing one on the different parts of the body. The phrase "fuck, help me" was the most censurable, I will not quote the rest of the shouts of the soldiers and the words of those who were watching. It went on like that for half a minute, maybe more, until a worker, who had fallen on the ramp, came out of his stupor and gave the drowning men a hand. The muddy soldiers in drenched uniforms were taken away somewhere, probably to treat us to a 40-degree sedative, and the "presentation" of the machine was over. We had a smoke break, discussed what had happened and went back to work. Contrary to expectations, no one was "in trouble". And later it became known that our "black box" was allowed by the military, although a couple of tests after the visiting committee of "free pool" (so we had a joke) the device was not used. PS. Before the arrival of high officials product of course previously subjected to all tests, except for bathing in the notorious aquarium, can this prototype still flies on one of the "Russian Avaks.

It was in the Army. I went to the Irkutsk Military Aviation School with my brother. We were twins. Not exactly alike, but you can't really tell at once. Once, when passing exams, my brother got into the infirmary (they put him to bed). But how could he take the exam if they wouldn't let him out of the infirmary (the army, damn it)? I refused to take the exam for both of them at once, but why not to lie in my brother's place while he was taking it? So I took the exam that day, ran to the infirmary, and changed clothes with my brother. The thing was that I had never been in the infirmary and had no idea where anything was. So my brother explained: go up to the first floor, enter such-and-such a ward, find such-and-such a bed in such-and-such a row, it was yours! Without any problem I found the bed and went to sleep. I lie there, rejoicing in life. I think I'll get some sleep after the exam. Five minutes later a nurse comes in and says: "Gov for a shot!" I'm thrown out of bed, screaming: "What shot? I'm fine." She's like, "I don't know anything. I'm waiting in the Procedure Room." I think I'm in trouble, that's it! I'm about to get skinned for my brother. I'm thinking, what do I do? And I got this crazy idea to sit in the bathroom. I was in the bathroom for 20 minutes. I think it's time to come out. I crawl out of the toilet, thinking I'm gonna sneak into my room. I see some lady standing there in a dressing gown. She sees me and says, "Oh, Gov, take these cans to the canteen." P-o-o-o!!! How do I know where the canteen is? So I take the cans and walk down the corridor, hoping I'm going in the right direction. Madam of the joint presses on me: like what is it that he is slowing down? I walk down the corridor, cursing my brother and reading the signs on the doors. On the last door, I see a sign saying "Canteen". Oh, thank God! Found it! I threw those cans in and raced to my room. And just as I was laying down, this nurse came back: "Gov, how long can we wait for you? Let's go." And that was it! I finally got my shot of penicillin in the ass for my brother. Then we laughed for a long time, especially me...
