Apparently having already seen tits through his natural binoculars, Musa immediately became tense along with his little brother. - Nah, I'm not taking my panties off," he declared. Despite the fact that our secret journey would be exposed at the first sight of Musa, we still tried to persuade him to take off those blue, washed out HB shorts, for which our army is famous, which we succeeded not without difficulty. Musa was all right. And here we were in the middle of the lake, swimming like real Germans, the first fragments of naked bodies were already being flashed, women's voices were already being heard, and we were almost on the shore. Preemptively suppressing all natural instincts, which were not affected even by the cold water, Igor and I went to the shore, trying not to look around, and settled down on the sand, as if nothing had happened. Only then did we discover that Musa was standing waist-deep in the water with his mouth wide open and his eyes wider open. The nearby Germans grinned. A parachute with Cyrillic letters peeped out of the bushes of hair on Musa's chest, but Musa still believed that he looked like a German. We started to give stealthy signs saying, "Come on out. Musa shook his head in a strange way and answered in pure German: "Nein! Standing like a stone in the cold water for fifteen minutes, Musa attracted the attention of half the beach, causing smiles and encouraging phrases in German, shimmering red shades of embarrassment under his fur. Time to rescue a comrade, we thought. Going into the water and approaching him from the back, we started to gently push him to the shore. Musa resisted, swearing in Russian, for some reason, like radio operator Cat during the birth, revealing a military secret. Musa could not resist our pressure and found himself on the shore. Realising he could not deal with us easily, he fell on his stomach. But as the secrecy of our operation had already been compromised, laughing out loud and waving everything we could, we dragged Musa by the arms onto the sand to the resounding "I'm your mother's laugh" and applause of the onlookers. Musa stayed like that the whole time on his stomach, attracting the local females to us. As a result, Igor and I several times went AWOL in the nearest village to our newly baked girlfriends, but without Musa. Z.I. Musa ran very fast back into the water).

There was a pilot in our regiment, and he was famous for landing on a forced landing on a jet plane with a stalled engine four times. The fourth time was the funniest). The deal was this. The airfield was on the Lena River. I took off all right, but at 600 metres I got a stalled engine. I have to say that jets without engine power fly like bricks thrown out of windows. So what to do? Below him there's a town, but straight ahead is Lena, straight as an arrow, the ice is thick, it's winter outside. he dives the plane and heads for the river. I have to add, that he flies to the training ground, there are bombs under wings, rockets, in general the view is fantastic. Anyway, he lands on its belly and glides over the ice, gliding well - the speed is really high. He glides for two kilometres, stops, opens the cabin lantern and sees a man, five metres away, fishing. and, of course, he can't hear a thing. Then our brave pilot unbuckles his oxygen mask and yells: "Hey, buddy, you got my hole!" The guy turns around and when he sees what the fellow is fishing with, he gives such a jerk, that according to the pilot it would be impossible to catch up with him even on afterburner. Such a story happened in our glorious Air Force, when paraffin was plentiful...

This was a real-life incident that happened to me in the mountains of the Caucasus in the spring of '95. I was studying then in Krasnodar at Faculty of Journalism of Moscow State University (Kuban branch) and was regularly in the mountains with a backpack in the company of the same amateur (and self-motivated) tourists. Out of equipment - at the best, a few meters of rope, sometimes an ice-axe. That time we were climbing Achishkho mountain. Who doesn't know, it's in the outskirts of coming Olympic Games. Then, almost twenty years ago - the places are quite wild. We started to ascend on the second day, after spending overnight at some half-dead camping site. The mountain, in principle, is not difficult. There is nothing for a climber to do there, if only to train on cliffs. For the tourist it is the most suitable. The slope though steep, but it is quite possible to climb without special equipment. The main difficulty at that moment consisted in weather conditions. End of April - beginning of May. The slope, the mountain and plateau were covered with very thick layer of snow. A lot of deep cracks, avalanche danger still, of course. Plus to all strong wind with wet snow. In that hike in sub-zero temperatures I froze my left hand. I had an ice-axe in my right hand; it worked and did not get hurt. However, this is prehistory. At one "fine" moment when only a hundred metres remained to the pass and the steepness of the slope exceeded 60 degrees (I can lie, but it was very steep), clever me decided that it would be easier to go up to the left of the main group. As I was not in a bundle it was decided - done. I realized my mistake in only five meters. But it was too late to go down and I tried to return to the previous course horizontally. The snow underfoot was not too frozen, rather wet and unreliable. Anyway, I slipped and rolled down as well as a bobsledder. There was no fear, just a feeling that everything was not happening to me. At first I tried to slow down with an ice-axe. Then I picked up speed, was thrown up and my forehead hit something hard. My Afghan cap flew off my head, but the worst thing was that my glasses were torn off. With my eagle-eye-vision of -7 it was equal to almost complete blindness. And I flew like that, tumbling, for about two hundred metres. I woke up on the ground. I lay down and did not need anything. The most difficult thing was to make myself rise on my feet. I stood up and was shaking, I could not feel my arms and legs, but I could not feel any pain. I realised in my head that the march was ruined and that there was no way out for me without eyes - to the valley with a good guide. Minutes later I saw our commander Gennady Ognev descend from the top of the fog (unfortunately, he was killed in the mountains and is no longer alive). - Are you all right? - Alive, I think... - Now... Goes down a few meters and comes back with my cap. - Here, you'll catch a head cold. I ask him, slurring my words, if he has seen my glasses anywhere. Gennady laughs nervously and harshly observes that I have made better snow digging than any tractor and that my body has negotiated the cracks as well as a slalom racer. So, the glasses will be found by archaeologists in 25 thousand years. And here is where the unbelievable happens. The commander suddenly leans over and pulls out glasses from under the sole of my left shoe. ALL OF THEM! - Well, boy, you're gonna live a hundred years. I never would have believed such luck if it hadn't happened to me personally. ... And half an hour later, at the pass, Svetlana from our group was feeding us from her hand with chocolate, her own hands were not working. ... And the next night I saw a real ghost in the premises of an abandoned weather station near Achishkho. .

We were celebrating a girl's birthday one day. Myself and some of her important fellows were on time, but the rest of the guests were late. For obvious reasons, no one waited for the latecomers - the party was in full swing. Those who showed up were simply given a penalty ticket and welcomed into the friendly company. By the time about 30% of the guests had arrived, everyone was pretty gassed. The ringleader went to the toilet. A few minutes later we hear a drunken girl screaming from the toilet: - Open the door!!! We, like true gentlemen, simply could not leave the lady in distress and, with a friendly hooting, carefully removed the door to the toilet from the hinges. The first thing we heard from the girl sitting on the throne in the posture of a proud eagle were the words: - DOLLARS! OPEN THE FRONT DOOR....

It was during the second campaign in the Chechen Republic. A group of heroes, having successfully completed their mission and reached Mazdok without losses (those who know what I mean), was waiting for the plane in the camp at the airfield. At the time there was a transit base in the area of the Mozdok airfield, a large tent village (or small tent city, whatever you liked) with streets, alleys, a headquarters (town hall), a canteen and so on and so forth attributes. They were given two tents at the edge of the village, but everyone got into one (the collective), and after buying an anti-stress drug for the last voyage money from the local pharmacy they went into nirvana (the plane was due to arrive the next day morning). Among the heroes was a canine specialist with a dog (a spaniel bitch) nicknamed Katya. Waking up in the morning he did not find the dog that had been asleep all night. Thinking that Katya had gone out to do dog stuff and finding herself in the same need, only human, the dog handler came out of the tent and found his partner not within sight, began to call first softly so as not to wake up the camp, and then louder - Katya, Katenka, where are you? With this he went round all the streets and alleys of the camp, but the dog was nowhere to be found. And then he had a terrible thought (reinforced not yet fully vaporized vapors of anti-stress medication) - The dog is lost!!! The flight's in a couple of hours, there's no way to cancel it, so it's a total fiasco! With those thoughts and groaning in a full voice - Katya, Katya, where are you my girl, went out into the main street (where the staff, mess hall, etc.), which had already overlooked the takeoff. Just then a girl's head peeks out of one of the tents and playfully says, "I'm here", and at the same time Katya appears from the next tent, expressing her guilt over the crime (she was obviously going for the smell of food). A man's tear rolls up from the tent, but his soul demands retribution and the soul gives out in the camp: Oh you s-s-s-bitch, oh you pr-r-o-hostess, sneaking around in other people's tents. In a second the camp is covered by a wild cackle. It turned out (well, coincidentally) lieutenants / crew celebrated the birthday of a local soldier Katerina, which lasted until morning and no one expected that not the camp will temporarily have a namesake and it will happen to her bad story, which is still long after remembered.
I heard some of the stalkers did their service in the hot spots. Do you know anything about the Afghan and Chechen wars? Maybe eyewitness accounts?
Thanks.

An acquaintance of mine told me a story recently. I'll tell it to you now. The intelligence section of the 5th Directorate of the KAD managed to infiltrate an agent into the Dushmans. In Pakistan they turned him over and sent him back to Kabul with a mission to blow up a school, gave him two kilos of plastic explosives, a meter-long piece of fire wire and two detonator caps. He brought all this to the KAD and reported his assignment. The KGB advisers asked me to examine it and give an opinion: was it really an explosive? I nibbled off a piece of plastic and held up a lighted match. People jumped to their sides. The plastic flashed brightly. The cord of fire ignited properly, too. Everything is fine, the quality is excellent. To test the detonator capsules, one of them will have to be tried out. However, the councillors did not want unnecessary noise in the location. They wondered what to do next. Blowing up the school was not an option and neither was failing the agent's verification mission. The school was located near the airport and was a two-storey wooden structure, similar to a barn. I had my eye on "imported" explosives and suggested to the councillors: - Guys, give it to me. Imported explosives are needed for foreign actions. In return, I'll make you a bomb out of Soviet plastic. The explosion will be a blast: windows will blow out in the whole area, and the school will be unharmed. The senior councillor squinted slyly: - 'Or maybe you've decided to register it as your trophy? - Ugh! - I took offence and left. The next day I was the first to hear from my Afghan colleagues about a night-time Dushman sabotage. A patrol spotted a man in the dark, fiddling with a cable well near the school, and called out to him. The unknown man took off running. Sarbozes [4 - Sarboz is a soldier] leaned over the manhole to see what was the matter. At that moment an explosion was heard. Two soldiers were injured. On top of that, the power cable shorted out and the wooden school burned to the ground. In the morning, I congratulated the councillors on the successful operation. They went pale and rushed to their underlings. They came back sour and reported to their bosses. The chief took a philosophical view of what happened: - "What a great job we did scrambling the agent!

I heard something. That's what our mentor at Cordon told us at the campfire. I'll tell you about it. An unarmed Hoshal approaches the gates of the villa where our hero has taken refuge. Just at his misfortune a jeep rides up. Hoshal is shot in the neck at point blank range with a submachine gun. Soldier of the operational regiment saw Hoshal fall and hit the jeep with an RPG-7. Two more militants sneak along the wall. Wounded and knocked out by a nearby grenade blast, Hoshal retrieves the pistol he has just been shot with and shoots the insurgents. Hoshal is carried away. The car is on fire. The villa lurks. A friend, Rashid, appears on the scene. He commands the grenade launcher to open fire on the windows. However, both grenades go just above the roof and explode somewhere in the city. Rashid sends a driver with the keys to his office. He has four American-made M-72 disposable grenade launchers (my gift) hidden under the couch. Soon the driver returns with the grenade launchers. Rashid carefully puts a round in each window. Screams are heard, smoke is billowing. The sobered and frightened prince from the basement calls the MGB on the phone, asking for a ceasefire. He has a pile of dead bodies. He surrenders. We visit Hoshal in the hospital. There are two automatic riflemen standing by his bed and room door 24 hours a day," the prince managed to order his subordinates to eliminate the entire Operational Regiment command together with the advisers. He was, of course, overreacting. We had absolutely nothing to do with it. However, our leadership has sounded the alarm: - Fuck them and a few advisers, it will be worse if we lose Kandahar! The prince must not be killed, he must be pacified. He was immediately sent to Sochi on a special flight with two faithful wives. He took two sacks of money with him: one with dollars, the other with the cheques of the foreign trade company. In fairness it should be noted that the father-king publicly condemned the prank of his unwise offspring. On his return from the Union, the prince returned to his fiefdom, Kandahar. However, the relatives of the slain fighters lashed out at the prince. He fled behind the cordon. He soon sent a tearful letter to a KGB adviser, inviting him to visit...Pakistan. Hoshal recovered quickly. Amazingly, the 9mm Makarov bullet went through between the trachea and carotid artery without hitting any vital nerves, vessels or skeleton. Rashid found himself in the fool's role as the blood enemy of his friend and drinking buddy of yesterday. Gotta get ready for a showdown.

Yes, the older lads at the bonfire used to say that. A while ago, one of them told me this. A narrow path, a ditch with water winds next to it. Dense bushes all around. You could not see anything further than a few meters. The path winds and disappears around a bend. Ambush on the head! A 50-metre stretch of detonating cord, a hand grenade is tied to it every 5 metres, ten grenades in all. All this is placed in a ditch with water and camouflaged with grass on top. This time we'll detonate using an electric detonator. The rings of the grenades are pulled out. Their triggers are held in place with twine wrapped around the cord. Having brought the enemy patrol close, the bomber presses the button. Explosion! What would a normal soldier do if the explosion came within half a metre of his foot? Naturally he would fall on the path. If even the mujahedeen quickly come to their senses and turn their heads to the sides, it's too late: there are grenades lying all around. Grenades popping off! Now our machine gunner should flush the remaining spirits to the ground with long bursts in the bushes while the bomber runs off at full speed! Since the head patrol moves in the "green zone" at a distance of visibility (5-10 meters) from the core of the column, we will certainly snag five to seventeen "ghosts" with our grenade mines. We do not need any trophies. Our task is to hit them properly so they would not walk in our street again. We'll use RGD-5 grenades for training purposes. In a combat situation, we'll have to use F-1s. The F-1's solid kill radius is 3.7 meters. We'll reduce it to 2.5 meters to be sure. So, if a grenade explodes every five meters in the enemy column, even if it is spread on the ground, it will not be a problem. Tests at the range showed that detonating cord could throw F-1 grenades from 0,5 to 15 meters.

Many people didn't want to remember that. From the words of an experienced soldier I will tell you a story. As the workload of the Pagman School increased, so did the number of accidents. No fatalities, though. I had a few accidents myself. The main reason for the "accidents" was that we used only captured ammunition, often spoiled in dungeon pits (I was not given anything else). Thus, every third or fourth 82mm mortar round failed to fire. Can you imagine how nerve-racking it was to take it out of the barrel? The shots of Chinese RPG-2 grenade launcher caused much trouble as well: their high-explosive charges, filled with black, smoky powder, had a bad habit of getting damp. As a result twice instead of firing the powder slowly burned down and the grenades fell out of the barrel several meters away from the shooter. One, thank God, did not explode. The other, bursting, hit three men, including myself, with shrapnel. The incident happened during the second business trip. At the villa, soaping up under the shower, I found a lot of small pimples on my body, which for some reason scratched my palms. I took a closer look - small splinters. I had to dig them out with a needle. My bunkmate Alexander Ivanovich, seeing my green-soaked belly, became alarmed: - Go to the doctor, you might get septicaemia! - Yeah, the doctor will report me to his superiors, I'll get a slap on the wrist and I'll be banned from work. I found a large piece of shrapnel in a leather wallet in my trouser pocket: it was stuck without penetrating a thick wad of money, an Afghani. Had the shrapnel hit a palm width to the right, the case would have ended sadly. On this occasion adviser Vitaly the next day told a fresh anecdote: - Beck was returning from a business trip, his wife was happy to see him and asked what present he had brought from Afghanistan. And sad Beck pulls a dried-up man's body on a string out of his pocket. Another reason for the accidents was that I was still training "expendable material" at the Special Forces school. The needs of the front demanded a large number of skilled fighters. They should not be afraid of close explosions and whistling bullets. As an example, I can compare the performance of two teachers sent from Moscow: in six months my colleague, who trained pyrotechnicians for a special laboratory, graduated ten Afghans. Over the same period, I trained more than a hundred Special Forces soldiers. But that doesn't mean their training was inferior. Observant Afghans have drawn the conclusion that explosions are feared either by totally ignorant people or by professionals who know a lot. My students, it turns out, occupied an intermediate level of semi-professionals who were not afraid of anything. What happened during the class did not happen. Once they shot themselves under their feet with an AGS-17; another time a heavy trophy 82mm mortar bomb fell twenty meters away from the shooters. The cadet mistakenly filled the mine with a cartridge from a 12-gauge hunting rifle instead of the standard knockout cartridge. A nightmarish episode occurred when an OZM-72 pop-up mine went off in the Afghan's hands! If it had exploded, two thousand pellets would have turned us into minced meat! Fortunately it had no primer, so it just flew twenty metres in the air, tangentially hitting an Afghan on the forehead and knocking him out - and us all around fell into a deep stupor for a few seconds. The cadets were quite often scratched while throwing hand grenades RGD-5 and RKG-3m while standing. There were two explosions while picking up unexploded ammunition at the range. The main thing at the range is to take care of your eyes, you need to wear protective glasses. One unpleasant incident is particularly memorable. I was conducting training sessions on hand grenades with a group of Special Laboratory of 5th Department of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine. I have plenty of these trophy grenades. All grenades are conditionally divided into two classes according to the type of fuse: instantly firing and grenades with retarder, which detonate several seconds after being thrown. The first type includes our antitank RKG-3, another one - shaped with parachute, with plastic body in the form of half-liter bottle, either Chinese or Pakistani manufacture, our antipersonnel RGO and RGN, and also a defensive grenade of absolutely nightmarish design, manufactured in Egypt. It was cylindrical in shape, with enameled casing, wrapped in the middle with thin elastic metal band. It was pierced through with a pin-check, and the ring of the check had a lead seal. When the pin is pulled and the grenade is tossed the elastic spring is unwound in flight and flies away from the case. When the grenade touches the surface, it explodes. The worst thing is that underneath the casing there are metal gears that break into numerous fragments the size of a pinky fingernail when detonated. The second class includes our conventional F-1, RGD-5, RG-42 with UZRGM primers and similar British, American and Belgian primers. The same is applied to German F-1s with long wooden grip and American M-46 with chisel igniters. So, I told my Afghan friends about the structure of grenades and rules of their handling, and took them to the range. I explained that the instant-action grenades should be handled carefully, thrown high and far, and should be hidden immediately. With grenades of the second class one can be especially unceremonious, for example, even F-1s should not be thrown, but simply lowered behind the muzzle. One fool has mixed up everything and has thrown the Egyptian instant grenade not far away. It fell in the liquid mud and didn't explode because the spring hadn't had time to unwind all the way. I warned the officer on duty about the failed grenade and instructed the sergeant to destroy it with an overhead charge. He did not. After lunch, the Afghan lieutenant went to that area to take a leak and, seeing an interesting toy, picked it up. It clicked and the spring bounced off. He threw it aside. Explosion! Like a razor, one of his legs was pulled off down to the knee. There was a more unfortunate incident with an American M-46 grenade in the 40th Army. A lieutenant-paratrooper decided that if it had a teeter-totter igniter like a rocket launcher, then it was a smoke grenade. Seeing the soldiers in the smoking room, he decided to play a joke, pulled the string and threw it into the middle. The soldiers did not move. The result was a dozen dead bodies. The officer shot himself. I averaged one or two accidents a month. In this context, it is difficult to describe my psychological state: it could probably be called fatalism. What else was there to do? After all, you could not in any way show the cadets timidity and fear. An instructor must be an absolutely fearless person. In the end, fatigue gradually builds up, which even alcohol does not relieve. Nervous breakdowns begin, sometimes for no reason at all.

I was wrong to remind you. This is a sore subject for many. But let me tell you a story. The operational regiment commander (by then our battalion had grown into a regiment) invites his advisers to attend the Eid al-Mairam celebration. But the leadership, being afraid of possible excesses, didn't allow us to participate in a Muslim feast. The Afghans sulk at us. The regiment's logistician gets upset: - We have bought 20 thousand Afghanis worth of snacks, and you did not come! It is a mortal insult. Seryoga instructs me, as a Muslim, to settle the incident. Besides, I was on a business trip in the province at the time, so I didn't seem to have anything to do with what had happened. I swear to my partners that the advisers had nothing to do with this and that we too are worried about what happened. We are ready to make amends. The next day we arrive at the regiment as a group. In the "tablet", in addition to several litres of cognac, vodka, champagne and a case of dry wine, we brought a number of assorted rifles. On the regimental firing range we spread cloak tents. On them we lay German machine gun MG-42, nicknamed "Hitler's saw", machine gun PC, American rifle M-16, and our RPK, AKS-74. Two interpreter soldiers fill the horns and load the machine gun ribbons. After three obligatory toasts I announce a competition: a glass of alcohol to the one who hits the target! The Afghans do their best: the shots rattle. Gradually everyone gets excited. Outside my head I see Din Mamad creeping back as soon as the shooting starts. While everyone is competing in accuracy, he manages to knock over an extra glass, obligingly set up by the interpreter, and crawls back to the firing line. We all like the MG-42: rate of fire is 1300 per minute and there is almost no dispersion: at 800 meters it shoots a line at a small target! Having shot off ammunition and liquored up with champagne, in the arms of the partners we return to the headquarters. The incident is over. Mamad, a big, slightly slouching fellow, who had joined the battalion from the commandos, his hands were a rake to his knees, was buzzing in my ear: he suggested we go to Kabul to see the girls. He has a good "henhouse" there somewhere. He only has the strength to get to his bunk. So he passes out with his eyes open. I close his eyes: - Sleep well, friend Dean Mamad...

An acquaintance of mine told me a story recently. As soon as we entered the Chechen fighters' sector of control, she called off their commander and said something for a long time, pointing at me. Then she said to me: "They thought you were an FSB agent, they wanted to shoot you or take you to the mountains, but I defended you. Of course, I was grateful, but if you think about it logically, who could call me a member of the secret service? Maybe they just didn't believe her, or didn't have time to deal with me? After '96 her son, named Ruslan, gladly helped me get around all over Ingushetia, first in his nine-car porsche and then in a sports car. There was not much to talk about except women, but he was very handy for work. An acquaintance nonetheless. "Brother"... On the eve of October 4, when he volunteered to drive me to a checkpoint in Mozdok, one thing struck me. Ruslan told me that he had a beautiful girlfriend, whom he went to see almost every night, and then told me that he was married, with two children. I asked: "Does the wife know? What does she say?" He replied calmly, "What to tell her? She's crying." There was such cruelty in that calmness that I felt uncomfortable.

I heard something. I will tell it from the mouth of an eyewitness. On the morning of the 4th October I overslept. Barely rinsing myself off, I grabbed my belongings and went down to the hotel lobby. Ruslan was already there. I was embarrassed that he had to wait, and I hustled around checking out of the hotel and paying for all the phone calls. Neither when we were driving round Nazran and Ruslan ran to his various addresses, nor on the Nazran-Malgobek highway did I remember that I had forgotten my passport at the hotel reception. Nor did any suspicions arise. I would have arrived in Mozdok by lunchtime anyway, and I might even have had time to be accredited by the press centre of a group of federal troops preparing to rush into Chechnya. With luck I might even have been stationed at the base of some forward unit by the evening. With luck... The decision to sell me probably only arose in Ruslan's mind when he returned to Nazran, when he resumed visiting various addresses. I can imagine the following conversation: "I have a journalist sitting in my car... - Yes? Who is he? - I think he's from "Moscow News". - Alone? Yes... - Wait, wait... Well... Go to Mohammed's house, tell him everything, tell him to get his guys together quickly. Got it? And then go to the hospital, find Said there. He'll settle up with you. You'll decide with him where to set up the place.... Ruslan did a good job for his money - I had never even thought of such a thing. The day was warm and sunny in the summer, I had submitted a story and it was published in the issue; there were five more days of business trips ahead, which meant the chance to distinguish myself and do something special for the paper. Anyway, the mood was great...

Yes, the older guys around the campfire were occasionally picking on me. The narration will be based on the words of an eyewitness. In the first few days in captivity I recalled the moment of capture with horror and pain. Stupid, bastard cattle, greedy creatures who thought they were supermen! The bombing had already been carried out with terrible force, the federal troops were on full alert, and the situation did not have any intention of kidnapping people - this was not '97, when thugs were simply beside themselves with impunity, stealing journalists one by one! After all, the federal troops may be all, but they are not the rabble that Maskhadov referred to as the "presidential guard" and "subunits of the Ministry of Sharia State Security". However decayed the Russian army may be, it is impossible to imagine its officers taking part in kidnappings of outsiders, as the Chechen bandits in uniform in sovereign Ichkeria did! Now, remembering the terrible moment when the Juda left me alone in his car in the back of the republican hospital, and he went to his allegedly beautiful friend, and an unremarkable white Chechen car with Ingush number plates stopped nearby, I realize that such a silent and swift operation was only possible because I was momentarily confused. Had I had had time to yell my head off, or at least to start a fight, things might have turned out differently. There was a busy place just around the corner from the hospital - a bus stop, a few commercial pavilions. This finally relaxed me, and when a blond man in military uniform without shoulder straps looked through the door of the Porsche with the window rolled down by the prudent Judas: "Your papers! Passport regime check", I again thought nothing wrong. I simply got out of the car and walked towards the white 'six'...

I didn't want many people to remember this, but it happened. It was our life. My ex-partner told me the story. I'll tell it in his own words. Shoving me into the backseat of their six, the thugs were wheezing in my ear: "Shut up, bitch! I'll kill you!!..", and they poked me in the side with the barrels of their pistols for reassurance. The plastic bag quickly ran out of air and I began to suffocate. All the more so as I tried to scream incessantly. From that moment on, time crumpled up for me like a piece of paper. I remember that the car immediately rushed through the streets of Nazran, someone's steady hands grabbed my belted purse containing all my documents and money, and my commander's wristwatch, a gift from my mother, the one I dived in Crete in '98, someone was pressing my head forcefully to their lap, and somewhere in the outside world, outside the plastic bag, the bandits were talking in broken Chechen or Ingush, in broken sentences. I remember that in shock I shouted nonsense like: "Basayev will kill you for me! Let me go, or you'll be sorry! Please don't shoot me! Then kill me, don't take me anywhere!" The bandit poking me in the side with his gun yelled: "One more word - I swear I'll shoot you like a dog right here!" - and hit me with the butt of the gun somewhere above my ear. Not hard, but very painful. Very soon I was weakened by the lack of air. I gasped and was no longer demanding, but begging to breathe a little. The car was still racing at full speed and, as far as I could tell now, all the time on tarmac. I wheezed out: "You Chechens! Better slaughter, don't choke!" One bandit replied: "We're not Chechens. We are Arabs," and all four of them cackled in a disgusting, vile, deliberately nasty voice. But the edge of the bag was lifted, and the air in the car, reeking of the bodies of the five sweaty men, seemed as refreshing as a sea breeze. Then they put him in another car: "Get out, bitch, quick, I'll kill you! Come here! Come here!" - and then to a third car. The bandits changed everywhere. In the second car, they were "kind" - they lifted the bag so that I could breathe not only through my mouth but also through my nose and gave me a smoke. In the third car they were "bad" again, silent and embittered. I remember the softness of the ground when they put me under a fruit tree ("Aha, it's not far from Assinovskaya! There used to be a fruit and berry state farm here. Salam alaikum, Chechnya...". I was lying down, my arms and shoulders were stiff from the ropes, and the two machine gunners were forbidding me even to move, so as to somehow reduce the unbearable pain in my shoulders. After five minutes or an hour, I heard the sound of a car approaching from behind the trees. The thugs picked me up with kicks (my hands were twisted, incredibly difficult to stand up) and drove off again like a sheep, accompanying me with meaningless evil shouts. It was already dark when they took me to the zindan. My new place of residence (not for long, just for a fortnight, as I found out later) was an unfinished garage among the ruins and piles of broken bricks.I could not believe then that just a few hours earlier I had been free, able to plan my next steps and "sway" if anyone wanted to interfere. Now I can't believe that I was the hostage - and therefore not quite human, and not even human at all - and that any of the bandits, at their own mind and mood, would have done anything to me with complete impunity.

You should have reminded me. This is a sore subject for many people. This is what our commander told us. Now that the wave of panic terror, pain and constant tension has subsided, I often think: could it have been otherwise? After all, all the circumstances that led to that fateful moment on October 4, 1999, at about 3 or 4 p.m., when four bandits took me away in their car, now look like a chaotic collection of coincidences and absurdities. If only I had not suddenly decided to visit acquaintances in Nasran the day before... If the bellboys at the Assa Hotel there had not been such charming and affable girls, whom I did not wish to offend with mistrust (I had gone up to them two days before the seizure, and jokingly and sternly asked them "Won't you lose my passport?" The girls got worried and offered to give it back to me, to which I replied, "No, no, you'll have it safer - I always lose everything")... If it wasn't for my damned forgetfulness... If only Ruslan had had an old Zigulenok instead of a sports two-seater Porsche, which offers a fast and comfortable ride to Mozdok... Every business trip is made up of these "ifs", be it to a "hot spot" or a safe country. But no matter how many business trips I have had in the years I have worked for Moskovskiye Novosti, the circumstances have always worked out as best as possible. Probably the limit of luck was exhausted, and on that last trip to Ingushetia something bad would have happened on the eve of the next big war. Luckily it was "only" hostage-taking. Luckily there was always a little hope, even on the darkest of days.

An acquaintance of mine told me a story recently. Or rather it was not even a story, but an eyewitness account. Thinking back now on the people who have known me since '96, who called me "nephew" and "brother" and who set bandits on me in cold blood, I feel a quiet, quiet disappointment, apart from a deafening anger and desire for revenge and hatred. Not so much in their decency as in their intelligence. What a stupid and greedy person I had to be to bring me into the clutches of the bandits without any disguise or trace! There were only two explanations for this treachery when I was still in prison: either they thought I was a complete fool, unable to draw the simplest conclusions, or they had been told that I would not stay alive. The second explanation made me sick. I shall not name the "tipsters" - the mother and the son - although their name has already appeared in the Moscow News. The couple are now in pre-trial detention, and the story of my capture is just a small episode in the rampage of the merry family. Even before, in '96, the mother looked somewhat suspicious - she was too businesslike, too "tight-lipped" back then, with extensive links in international humanitarian organizations and among the Chechen fighters. She spoke of her unselfish and noble nature, of freeing Russian prisoners of war out of the call of her heart, and of the many times she had stared death in the face in this difficult task. To be fair, I should note that she was indeed not too afraid when the two of us went to the embattled Grozny on March 7, 96. At the time I did not understand why she wanted to do this.

I have heard something. Or rather, I read the former commander's latest sketches. Here listen. On April 4 at about 15.00 the gunner of the BMP shook us: "Stand up, we will go soon!" And really, in 15 minutes we moved forward... 600 meters to the road it took us an hour and a half. The spirits were above us, shooting at us like at a shooting gallery. The 2nd and 3rd platoons came to the road from our company, the 1st and control of the company remained in the position two hundred meters behind, the 2nd and 6th companies went around Gojskoe on the left. They decided to move behind the road, asked me to cover, but my SVD did not fire: a grenade fragment hit the bolt. I dismantled the rifle. There were some other pieces of metal in the receiver, it looked like splinters too. I checked everything, tried the rifle - nothing, works. Our group went behind the road, throwing grenades at the spirits. At first a pair of machine-gunners and a gunner attached themselves to the place. And already under a cover others left. We knocked out the spirits from the position. By all appearances there were about twenty of them. Retreating, they left five for cover. Those poor bastards were blown to bits by grenades. Dug holes under the road didn't help them either. We're holding our ground. At the same time, the 6th and 2nd Companies were engaged in a heavy fighting in the "green area". Eleven men, together with the platoon commander, who was acting commander-in-chief, laid down there. Two weeks later the spirits asked us to take the corpses as they were already badly decomposed. But it was some time later; meanwhile we blocked the right flank of the 2nd and 6th companies. In one of the holes we found a live "Czech", who had managed to kill the kid who had found him. We tried to smoke him out - all in vain. We poured paraffin into the hole, set it on fire and threw grenades. Apparently, the entrance to the shelter was knee-jerk, so they didn't get to him... While the matter was settled, we looked, the main forces of the company approached. It appeared that they, having lost four men, could not overcome a field. Our platoon leader fought with the company because of their late approach. The platoon leader shouted: "No clear instructions from the commander!" Platoon leader: "Kombat's drunk. You should have made the decision yourself!" While they were sorting things out, we examined the Chechen trenches and dugouts, finishing off the wounded. After a while, the command: "Stand back!" That this is nonsense is clear to everyone. One of the conscripts-debates tried to explain by radio that we should secure our position, because if we will not come here, the spirits will come, and we again will have to occupy a position with losses. He shouted until hoarseness, with foul language, but, certainly, he could not convince anybody. After ensuring the withdrawal of the 6th Company we started to move back. SAU from the 324th infantry battalion began to hammer Goyskoye, and we were divided into two groups. The first moves with all stuff, the second covers. As a whole, they departed normally, but it was not without jokes. The tank number 420 was the last to depart. It covered everybody, "as much as possible". During the assault, the spirits burned two BMPs: one of ours, and one of the 6th Company. To be sure the tank hit the wrecked BMP. And then some gunner-operator from the "two's" hit it with a bang! Tankers said later: "Of course we didn't give a shit, but when during retreat their own people hit you in the ass...". Who shot, they never found out.

Some of the older guys around the campfire used to do it. One of them must have been a former soldier. That's what he told them. It is dirty and boring, newcomers from some brigade of the Airborne Troops move around. For three whole days we worked with paratroopers to turn Khankala into an impregnable fortress. It is a little calmer now. The spirits have stopped their absurd sorties at night, they do not harass us with any excuse. Our generals are too cowardly, they assigned an entire brigade of the Air Force and a battalion of paratroopers to protect tiny Khankala, and they promise to send another regiment of motorized riflemen. Where will they be accommodated? But this is all lyric, and there is nothing to do at the moment. I'm going to radio operators, I should be informed, otherwise the war will be over and you'll never know. - Hello, "Broomstick". - And "Moscow", do you have a smoke? - What's new? - Nothing, marines, paratroopers, motorized riflemen, and Sofrinsky are hitting Wait a minute, Dudayev the asshole won't give up, in short life is shit and the sun is a fucking the sun is a lantern! - Have you heard anything about our brigade? - Nothing concrete, we're waiting, while guarding the "jackal's command... I tried to tune in another wave on the radio but the crackling air was interrupted by "chukchi" guttural speech, I couldn't speak Russian so I continued walking... I was caught talking to some motorized rifle unit that was jamming the "spirits" in a five-storey block but I couldn't hear any callsigns etc. I heard a sort of abnormal mat which implied that Warrant Officer Zinoviev had a sexual relationship with a BMP in a place that was difficult to visualize on an BMP... Good thing stretch marks, another trip by the spirits after our Behemoths was spotted in time. Fat "Broom" during my radio intercepts had time to "sleep" and jumped up to about half a meter, he bettered up from the chair crawled around the body while trying to fit his armor, grenade pouch, and eventually he stumbled on the helmet and with a wild rattle fell to the floor. It would have been a lot of fun if it hadn't been so miserable. In a matter of seconds I reached my equipment, looking for my eyes platoon leader, aha over there he settled down behind a piece of rebar and with great enthusiasm hrynutsya over dushmanov ko because of the natural dullness of climbed out into the open area. Either we were really good troops, and not a herd of deer, as our commander told us in the "training camp", or the cadres we encountered were not very intelligent, but we held Khankala with good conscience, and there were practically no losses among the personnel. Two "200 hundred" in six days in January 95 in Chechnya is not bad, though it is very bad, because there could have been none. In a few minutes we assembled a combined platoon - a squadron in number - and set out to comb the area. Of course there were no spirits in the vicinity, we put up several tripwires and "torches" as there was no point in going around without our knowledge. Another day went by, another war... Who needs it all...

Many people did not want to remember it. This is an eyewitness account. After passing the militants' defensive lines in Grozny we got into neighbourhoods that were completely controlled by the "Dukhs". The army camouflage and our unshaven, blackened, sunken cheeks gave us every chance of passing for guerrillas in the event of a sudden meeting with the "warriors of Ichkeria. The guerrillas' mess was similar to that of our troops. In the conditions of general confusion among the insurgents, the system of badges and passwords sometimes did not work, and it was enough to shout "Allahu akbar" for us to be taken for insurgents. Our objective was to conduct reconnaissance of the territory behind the guerrillas' fighting lines, and disrupt the enemy's communication system by planting mines to create a feeling of chaos and panic in their ranks. They advanced exclusively in the evening, but before dark. As darkness fell, advancing through the town was dangerous, as at that time the warring parties were doubling down on all activities on the adjacent side. At night we lay low in smelly cellars or in abandoned houses in the private sector, which we had chosen after a preliminary reconnaissance so that all the entrances to our hiding place were clearly visible. It was already beginning to get dark. We have been circling in this area for two days now, unable to find a way into a neighbouring district crawling with armed guerrillas and bearded with green armbands. We have to sit this night out and leave for the next street at dawn. I noticed this afternoon that the exit to the neighbouring street marked on our map was turned by the militants into a stronghold in case of a breakthrough by Russian tanks, covered with various large-sized junk consisting of broken-down cars and a half-burned bus. My sixth sense told me that this improvised barricade was probably guarded by the "Dukhs", so I should not go there in haste. Having posted guards and an observer, we lay down to rest on a pile of broken bricks. The bricks dig into our backs and the tension in our bodies prevents us from getting to sleep. I roll over on my stomach and lie down on my folded arms, a posture that is not very comfortable, but I force myself to sleep as there is a hard day tomorrow. It was not what I would call sleep. I closed my eyes and fell into a trance of oblivion, continuing to somehow control my surroundings. I wake up suddenly. Silence. However, it became cold and uncomfortable in my stomach. After another moment at the same time I heard the crunch of debris, heavy footsteps and saw the cautiously prowling beam of a pocket lantern. "Spotted! Where's the watcher, is he lying there already with his throat cut?" - my condition was close to panic. I could not hear my comrades breathing nearby. So, they are awake, and just like me, huddled together in a pile of bricks. The men with the torch (it must have been a fighter patrol) stopped not far from the entrance to our shelter. There was a silence that seemed to last a lifetime. My heart went to my throat. "I must pull myself together. This morning I read the Lord's Prayer and God protect me", if not to calm me down, at least to get rid of the paralysing animal fear of the unknown and to prepare myself for action. The assault rifle is at my fingertips. The fingers of my other hand groped for the cold ribbed surface of an F-1 grenade, which had one sole purpose - not to be caught alive. The footsteps began to recede. "Not found." The tension had subsided. However, the anxiety for the guys who had been on the watch had not gone away. The conditioned signal. "Ours!" Two shadow-like figures slipped towards us. As it turned out, the fighters appeared suddenly from some basement, which we did not even pay attention to at first. When light began to fall, we cautiously left our hideout, having previously left a few "guests" in the form of two MON-50s. We went out of the cellar and after looking around we found a little-noticed passageway to the cellar, which on further inspection turned out to be a through passage to the street, which we had not been able to get to before. Having mined this passageway too, which the guerrillas would probably still try to use, our group infiltrated behind the "spirits" in the vicinity of the tram park. There was no reason for us to linger there. The tram depot and the adjacent territory were crawling with insurgents, because Maskhadov's headquarters was located there, and the guerrillas might have stumbled on our "guests" and realized that newcomers had entered their territory. Gathering intelligence by visual observation, and trying to dispose of the cargo as quickly as possible - by placing and concealing mines - we began to prepare for withdrawal. The route of withdrawal which we had worked out and coordinated with the command of the subdivisions to the line which we should have reached after the operation turned out to be useless. It would be more accurate to say that by this time, while we were behind enemy lines, the situation had changed. The lines of contact with the enemy had shifted, and in some directions the insurgents had established new strongholds. Given the situation, we had to conduct reconnaissance and look for new escape routes.

I should have reminded you. This is a sore subject for many. Listen to an essay by a veteran. In spite of the fact that there were guys in our group who had lived in Grozny before all these events, it was very difficult to orientate oneself in the ruined city. In some places there were enemy positions five days ago, but now they may be taken by our forces, so the possibility of being hit by the federal troops' fire is high. Although there are no "smart" deaths, it is foolish to take a bullet from one of our own. To avoid this we had to constantly carry out additional reconnaissance of the area. I witnessed the consequences in January 1995, when our reconnaissance team ran into our own people. Our reconnaissance group under command of Vadim ran into the Volga-Grad units (units of the 8th Army Corps commanded by General Rokhlin) in one of the Grozny districts. Lack of cooperation played a tragic role, Vadim's group was mistaken for the enemy by the Volgograds and was fired on to defeat them. One of the group was killed. Vadim jumped out of cover and started shouting: "Don't shoot! We are friendly!" When the fighters on the spot "arrested" him, it turned out that he didn't have his documents. When Vadim tried to explain himself to the men from Volgograd, he was severely beaten and almost shot. After the circumstances of the case had been clarified and a request for confirmation made to higher headquarters, Vadim, in critical condition, was taken to the hospital at Severny. I was standing at his bedside and it pained me to listen to his choppy, stuttering speech, where he was only repeating: "Y-you r-e-understand, I was k-i-n-tusiated in Afghan and I am through with it here ...". Two hours later he was taken by a special helicopter to Mozdok, then to the hospital in the "mainland". After running through a small square we cross an arch into a courtyard. It is as if from another life. The war has spared it so much that the ruins in the neighbouring streets give the impression that the arch through which we entered this courtyard is a gateway from one world to another. The silence is unaccustomed. A few minutes later we became convinced that silence in war can sometimes be deceptive. Trusting the silence and the apparent calmness, we made a mistake which almost led to a tragic outcome for us. We had broken the basic rules of movement in enemy-held territory, which state: "Do not trust your eyes or your ears. Trust only your gut and animal instinct. Check seven times..." and other principles according to which we have no right to ever relax. From the first floor window of a neighbouring house we were called out in Chechen. We were taken aback... Without getting an answer, they opened fire on us. But either the shooters turned out to be lousy, or maybe it was because those "animal instincts" had awakened in us again, only one man in our group received a light wound in the side, and even that was just a touch, as we were instantly behind the high concrete slabs, taking cover from the enemy fire. We did not want to waste ammunition so we decided not to focus on the enemy in the building and therefore in an advantageous position, especially as we did not know their strength and intentions. Being under the cover of the concrete slabs and bouncing back with short bursts of fire and single shots, we tried to buy time to make the "only right decision. Through the basement windows, one by one we made our way into the three-storey house behind us. Cursing and cursing ourselves for our carelessness, the first thing we did was to help the wounded man. Two went off to reconnoitre. The rest took up defensive positions. Those who returned from the reconnaissance brought good news: at some distance from us were the lines of the Russian troops assaulting the city. Apparently, the proximity of the federal troops did not allow the guerrillas who opened fire on us in the courtyard to take more decisive action against our group, entrenched in this three-storey building. Or perhaps it was an enemy group similar to ours, whose mission was not to engage in protracted open combat. In any case, we quickly established contact with the commander of the federal troops we had approached, and after an hour we were sent to the "Severny" station by APCs.

An acquaintance of mine told me a story recently. I'll tell it to you now. "The 'ceasefire' turned into a bloody tragedy the very next morning. At 10 in the morning, on the Staropromyslovsky Road, guided claymores set on the side of the road were detonated by Chechen fighters. Fragments of an exploded 152-mm howitzer shell (tank and howitzer shells are used by the guerrillas as the main explosive charge) pierced the armour of the APC, killing the driver's mechanic instantly. The unguided APC, travelling at 70 km/h, jumped out onto the opposite side of the highway and cut through a concrete light pole and stopped, covered in blood and splattered with the brains of the soldiers of the 101st Army Brigade who were on the armour. Four soldiers died in a matter of seconds, a fifth, whose legs were blown off, died on the way to the hospital and a sixth died on the operating table. Near the scene of the tragedy, an elderly Russian woman walked by, her face covered by the hides of her cloak, unable to hide her tears. She had to hide her tears from the crowd of Chechen youths who had gathered at the crossroads and were merrily discussing what had happened. On the same day, five Chechen fighters captured at one of the checkpoints were brought to the GYOSH. Dressed in black, more like a uniform, they were carrying weapons, half of which were fitted with silenced firing equipment. Having left Shali after the federal forces' operation led by General Shamanov in May 1996, this group attempted to penetrate Grozny. The leader of the group, as the investigation revealed, was at the same time the commander of the reconnaissance group of Shamil Basayev's detachment. The captured fighters testified that they had arrived in Grozny to carry out terrorist attacks. This was proved by the list of officials of the Chechen government, which was found with them, and the names and locations of their offices. During the interrogations, it became known that the fighters had also received orders to take the families and relatives of the fighters who were fighting in the mountains from Grozny by June 10. All this gave one reason to suppose that the fighters were using the "ceasefire" for their own purposes, and not peaceful ones at all. The atmosphere in Chechnya was becoming more and more heated by the day. The unwillingness of Russia's military and political leadership to live by the laws of a war that may not have been declared, but still a war, led to the tragic events in Grozny on August 6, 1996.

I have heard something. Just now a story comes to mind. It really happened a long time ago. My company was raised to disarm a Chechen scum, with the "Vovans" (Special Forces of the Interior Ministry) working, and we only covered the scene. When the Vovan commander was brought to the village elders, he demanded that they surrender 24 AKs within two hours. To which one of the elders began to fuck up in the style of Lukashenko. He stated that a legal self-defence squad was operating in their village, but they did not have enough assault rifles themselves, so the feds were obliged to immediately give him another 20 AKs. The Vovanians were a bit taken aback by such brazenness, but we were not confused. The fucking elder got a queue in bread cutter in front of everybody, and while his legs were still twitching, the rest of the elders heard a delicate request to hand over not 24, but 100 AKs. And not in two hours, but in an hour. The Chechens managed to surrender exactly 100 assault rifles in forty minutes. The moral of this story is as follows: politics and diplomacy are good for a partner who stays within certain limits. For a "partner" who has lost his edge, there has to be a different set of tools. I have seen convoys of buses, the stench of which made it impossible to get within 100 meters of, as they were full of the bodies of slaughtered Russians. I saw women, evenly sawn along with chainsaws, children, hanging on posts from road signs, intestines artistically wrapped around a fence. We Russians were scrubbed off our own land like dirt from under our fingernails. It was 1992 - there were still two and a half years before the "first Chechen war". And then things got really fun. Militants came to the village and began cleansing it of the Russians. Sometimes at night one could hear the screams of people being raped and stabbed in their own houses. No one came to help them. It was everyone for himself, everyone was shaking with fear, and some managed to base it on an ideological foundation, like "my home is my fortress" (yes, I heard that phrase just then. The man who uttered it is no longer alive - the Vainakhs have wound his entrails around the fence of his own house.) That is how we, the cowardly and stupid, were massacred one by one. Tens of thousands of Russians were killed, several thousand ended up in slavery and Chechen harems, and hundreds of thousands escaped Chechnya in their pants. This is how the Vainakhs solved the "Russian question" in a single republic. And they only succeeded because we were nobodies, complete turds. Even now we are crap, but not so liquid - among the crap there are grains of steel. And when these particles get together - condopogues happen. There are not many of them yet, but the Vainakhs are good. They are the true sanitarians of the forest. As a result of their cultural and educational mission in Russia, the Russian sheep are once again becoming human. Generally, those who have come across Chechens in their lives have reason to hate them.

The older guys used to say mean things around the campfire. Couple of veterans were there. Here, listen. There, in the war, fate brought me together with a Jew - Lev Yakovlevich Rokhlin. Originally our participation in the New Year's storm was not supposed. But when contact with the 131st motorized rifle division and 81st motorized rifle division was lost, we were thrown to help. We broke through to the 8th AC commanded by General Rokhlin and reached his headquarters. It was the first time when I saw him personally. And he did not seem to me at first sight: hunched over, with a cold, with cracked glasses... Not a general, but some tired agronomist. He gave us a task - to collect dispersed remnants of Maikop brigade and 81st regiment and bring them to Rokhlin's reconnaissance battalion. That was what we did - we gathered the pissed-out meat from the basements and led them to the position of Rokhlina reconnaissance units. There were about two companies in all. At first Rokhlin did not want to use them, but when all other groups retreated - the 8th AC was left alone in an operational encirclement in the centre of the city. Against all the fighters! Then Rokhlin lined up this "army" in front of his fighters and addressed them. It was a speech I will never forget. The general's most affectionate expressions were: "fucking monkeys" and "faggots". At the end he said: "The fighters outnumber us fifteen to one. And there's no help to be had. And if we are destined to lie here, let each of us be found under a pile of enemy corpses. Let's show how Russian fighters and Russian generals die! Don't let us down, sons..." Lev Yakovlevich is long dead - he was dealt with without you. One less Jew, isn't there? I already told you about Rokhlin's speech. But I have not told you what happened next. After that there was a terrible, terrible battle in which from my platoon of 19 men only six survived. And when the Chechens broke into our position and it came down to grenades and we realised we were all going to hell - I saw real Russian people. There was no fear any more. There was a kind of cheerful anger, a detachment from everything. There was only one thought in my head: "Batya" asked me not to let you down. The wounded men bandaged themselves, injected themselves with Promedol and continued to fight. Then the Vainakhs and I went into hand-to-hand combat. And they ran away. That was the turning point of the battle for Grozny. It was a confrontation between two characters - the Caucasian and the Russian, and ours proved the tougher. It was at that moment I understood that we could do it. We have this hard core in us, we just need to clean the crap out of it. In the melee we took prisoners. Looking at us, they weren't even whimpering - they were howling in terror. Then a radio intercept was read to us - Dudayev's order was passed over the guerrillas' radio networks: "Do not take prisoners and torture the spetsnaz from the Eighth AAC and the airborne special forces, but kill them immediately and bury them like warriors. We were very proud of this order.

Many people would not like to remember it. It was a turbulent time. There were gardens between Gojskaja and Komsomolskaja, and behind them the spirits had positions of anti-tank missiles. Their operator was cool, he hit the filler three versts away. Not only that, he tried to cover the checkpoint of the 324th regiment, fired at the checkpoint, and it was all four kilometres away. It was this PTU that the commander somehow aimed at us. We proceeded from the assumption that the position wasn't badly guarded, and if one wanted to shoot the operator, one would do it silently. Therefore we asked the commander to order a VSS "Vintorez" from the RAW depot. He prescribed the rifle, but someone had to go to collect it together with the head of the service of rocket-artillery armament. He and I decided to go to the regiment in a passing convoy. The situation in Gojskoye was as follows: the spirits could not turn the confrontation in their favor, as we outnumbered them in firepower (artillery, aviation, etc.), and we could not take Gojskoye because of our small number. Anyway, we got the spirits, and they told us that if any other unit of the 245th MSP would approach Goyskoye, they would close the gorge and blockade the regiment. It arrived in Nizhniye Atagi, where we waited for the column, at half past two. It was made up of demobilised conscripts from the raid group, and also of those who were on their way to the regiment on leave for family reasons. (Naturally, they, like me, were nowhere accounted for, and so later, when the fighting was behind us, the exact number of losses in our ill-fated column was quite difficult to calculate. In particular, the Ural with the demobees, of whom there were 20, burned down after a single Bumblebee hit. They were carrying food there, and the boys were sitting on sacks on top - so they all burned down...). I moved along the column to find out about the mail - there were no letters. When I went back, I saw four caravans in a row, and one of them had my good friend and fellow-countryman, Arkasha. It turned out he was the deputy leader of the tank squad. Well, that's lucky! "Arkasha, do you have an empty seat in the cockpit? It wasn't befitting a sniper - a white man - to be hovering in the dust on the armour. He says: "Come and have a look for yourself!" I went in, moved the bag with vodka, which he was taking to somebody for his birthday. That's all right, I'll fit in. At about 14.00 we set off. At 14.10 we have passed Chishki and before an input in the gorge the shutters were pulled. Arkasha says: "Look, there are only women and children". And just yesterday the guys from the 324th regiment told me an omen: "If there are men, women and children on the road - everything is normal. If it's just chicks - no way, soon it'll be an ambush." The column stretched on the "mother-in-law's tongue" (it's a serpentine road). The tankers could hardly turn around on it, and I don't know how the MAZ trucks, which were pulling the unserviceable equipment, got through. All is quiet, calm. We drive on, we tell jokes. We drove through Yaryshmardy, the head of the column has left behind a turn, the tankers have passed the bridge across the dry river bed. And here - an explosion ahead, we look - the tank turret was thrown up from behind a hill, the second explosion - somewhere in the head of the column, and the third one just bang between the forward going and our tank. The explosion tore the bonnet off and smashed the windows. That was the first time I was shell-shocked. Arkasha had already got out of the car, but I got tangled up in the two door handles. Eventually I fell out of the cabin. The fire was very dense, but I had already begun to think and ran away from the tank 15 metres away, in spite of the fire of the spirits. I found some hollow in the roadside and pushed my ass in it. Nearby, an enlisted man lay down. The first shock passed and I could see how things were going. And things were not good. Something was set on fire behind us and black smoke went towards us in the gorge, I couldn't see anything through the sight. My conscript Dmitry and I figured it was time to fuck off. We got ready and rushed across the road, fell behind concrete blocks before the bridge. We couldn't lift our heads, and the machine-gunner pounded the pours, and not unsuccessfully. He set them on fire. We were lying down with Dima, a meter and a half wide river of burning paraffin was running past us in the direction of the bridge. The flames were unbearably hot, but as it turned out, that was not the worst thing. When the fiery river reached the "Ural" with charges for SAU, all this stuff started to explode. I see, some things with rags fly out of the car. Dima explained, that it is illuminating shells. We lie down and count: Dima said there were about 50 of them in the car. Meanwhile the second "Ural" with high explosive shells caught fire. It is well that it did not detonate completely, the shells were scattered aside by explosions. I was lying there thinking: "Shit, why isn't anybody in charge of us? It turned out later that Khattab had planned everything so well that at the very beginning of the battle the entire control tower, which was equipped with the two command and staff vehicles, was cut down by small arms fire, and the armoured personnel car was left untouched for the whole battle. Suddenly something in the second "Ural" with high explosive ammunition has exploded so that the back bridge with one wheel as a candle has gone upwards for 80 meters and, by our reasons, it should have fallen down directly on us. Well, we thought we were done for. But we were lucky: it fell about ten metres away. Everything was in smoke, everything exploded. Can't see anything through the sights because of the smoke. The shooting is indiscriminate, but the machine gunner of spirits stood out against the general background. We decided to get out of this hell, ran over to the green area. We allocated sectors of fire together with Dima. I was firing at the front, and he was covering my rear, watching to prevent the spirits from coming from above. We crawled out to the edge, but the tank, which was at the tail of the column, was attacked by the spirits with RPGs. Eight times they hit, but without result. Then the turret at the side of the commander's hatch was punched through. Smoke started billowing from it. Probably, the crew was wounded and the mechanic began to fall back. So backwards he passed all column and, they say, reached the regiment. An hour has passed since the beginning of battle. Shooting began to stop. I said: "That's it, Dima, let's go to the end of the column!" We ran under the bridge, I look, there are seven people in Afghan clothes, and beside them there are two dead bodies. We run over. One of the sitters turns around. Oh my God! He had a black beard, a hooked nose and mad eyes. I raise my rifle, pull the trigger... The rest of them turn... ours. Good, I didn't finish it. The contract soldier had a beard. He was sitting dumbfounded without me, stammering, unable to say anything. I shouted: "Uncle, I almost killed you!" And he doesn't get it. BMP "limp" was crawling towards us, collecting wounded. It was hit in the torsion, and it waddles so. We threw the wounded inside, got on road - around the cars are burning, something in them bursts. The shooting almost stopped. We go. Somewhere nearer to Argun on the road the muzhiks shout: "Guys! We have wounded people here. Help!" I jumped over to them, but the car drove on. I go over to the guys. They say: "We've got a major wounded." There's a major sitting there in camouflage, with a badge on his sleeve. He's hit through the arm and chest. Pale from loss of blood. Only thing I had was a tourniquet. Tied his arm up. We got to talking and it was found out, that he was the deputy political officer of a battalion in the Pacific Fleet. At this time someone from the guys remembered that they had beer, cigarettes, juice, etc. in the car. I covered the guys and they ran off and brought all this stuff. We are lying, drinking beer and having a smoke. It began to get dark. I thought: "It's getting dark, the spirits will come down, no help, and we're screwed!" We decided to choose a better position. We took a hillside, occupied it, lay and waited. The guys from RMG show me the situation. Dukes used RPGs to burn the cars with ammunition, and the ones with food were simply pelted with small arms. The artillery strikes very deliberately - only along the slopes and not hitting either the populated area or us. Then four Mi-24s arrived and worked their way through the mountains. It got dark. We hear terrible rumbling from the direction of the 324th regiment. It appeared that support was rolling. Ahead of them was a T-72, BMP followed by a tank. Near 50 meters it stopped and aimed its gun at us. I think: "That's it! The spirits haven't killed - they will kill us in the heat of the moment! We rise up, waving our hands - as if they were ours. The tank swung a trunk, turned around and as though shoots in "green area" in 20 meters from itself. From this "help" the people jumped - they creep on the grass, pour around themselves from automatic rifles. We yelled to them: "Men, why are you crawling? There is nobody here any more". It appeared, it was a reconnaissance of 324-th regiment. I came up to officers and I say: "What you here fight? We should go to the head of a column!" And they to me: as you were here and also understand, take ten men and move with them where you told. I walked around, found some scouts, and we moved forward. I counted over forty burned corpses. Judging by which vehicles remained intact, the spirits had a clear indication of where everything was. For example, the medical MTLB remained untouched at all, only the mechanic was hit with small arms, and the ZUU behind it was literally turned into a sieve. Then we wondered why the help arrived so late: if they had arrived an hour and a half earlier someone would have survived in the head of the column, but the only BRDM had resisted to the end and almost everyone in it was killed. As the guys from the 324th regiment told us later, when they reported that our column was being pounded in the gorge and it would be a good idea to rush to their aid, they were told not to move and stay where they were. Help came to us two and a half hours later, when it was all over.
